FacilityName: Shell Oil Products United States- Lima Terminal

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The Shell OPUS - Lima Terminal has two separate operations:  a bulk petroleum gasoline storage and pipeline facility and a separate butane blending operation.  The butane blending operation is subject to certain requirements set forth in the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program regulations.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      This Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane blending system, which includes two storage tanks with a capacity of approximately 87,000 gallons each and associated piping.  The butane blending system was designed and constructed by MCE Blending LLC consistant with the applicable provisions in  the National Fire Protection Association 58 (2001Edition) Code for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The facility's worst case scenerio is the failure of the system's two manifolded 87,659 gallon storage tanks when filled to the greatest amount allowed (92.4% capacity at 60 Degrees Fahrenheit) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion due to a simultaneous and complete failure of both tanks.  The resulting distance to the endpoint (1 PSI overpressure) extends off-site 0.7 miles and includes public and environmental receptors.  The facility's alternate (most likely) release scenerio is a "pull away" accident resulting in a one minute pipe/hose release and explosion.  The resulting distance to the endpoint (1 PSI overpressure)

extends off-site, but does not affect residential areas based on EPA modeling.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         To date, there has been no accidental releases from the butane blending system that have resulted any known on-site deaths, significant property damage, or injuries that had an effect on a human that results either from direct exposure to toxic concentrations, radiant heat, or overpressures from an accidental release or from the direct consequences of a vapor cloud explosiion (such as flying glass, debris, or other projectiles) from an accidental release that requires medical treatment or hospitalization (hereinafter "injuries") or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           In the event of an emergency involving the butane blending system, it is the facility's policy to contact the Shawnee Fire Department and request their assistance, as necessary.  The facility maintains a trained fire brigade and hazardous materials response team to respond to minor accidents and the initial stages of potentially significant emergencies.  In addition, the Allen County LEPC is notified, as necessary.  The facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the fire department and the Allen County LEPC.  The Shawnee Fire Department is scheduled to participate in the initial PSM/RMP training sessi

on conducted for the butane blending system.  Certain types of emergencies may require the notification of the Local Emergency Management Services and St. Rita's Hospital.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           The Shell OPUS Terminal has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program covering the butane blending system.  This program covers the following activities for the butane blending system and associated operations:  Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, performing a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Operating Procedures, Process Safety Training Requirements, Pre-startup Safety Reviews, Mechanical Integrity, Hazardous Work Procedures, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, and PSM Compliance Audits.
